markdownRemark.html:
Introduction

var a = "5"
var b = a++
console.log(typeof b) // number
  • we might think a is changed after assigning its original value to b
  • but a change did happen to a before it was assigned
  • it was coerced to type number, hence the output
  • the spec is the most reliable source

Types in Javascript

  • types supported in javascript are undefined, null, boolean, string, symbol, number, bigint and object
  • functions, arrays are subtypes of the object type
  • in javascript, variables don’t have types, values do
  • typechecking happens at runtime, so javascript is a dynamically typed language

Coercion

  • coercion refers to converting from one type to another
  • it can be implicit or explicit
var students = 4
console.log(`${students} students`) // implicit coercion
console.log(`${String(students)} students`) // explicit coercion

typeof

  • returns a string, which shows the type of the argument
  • we can use utilities, e.g. Array.isArray when typeof isn’t enough
var v = "kyle"
console.log(typeof v) // string

v = 39
console.log(typeof v) // number

v = null
console.log(typeof v) // object

v = function () {}
console.log(typeof v) // function

v = [1, 2, 3]
console.log(typeof v) // object

bigint

  • numbers in javascript are represented by the IEEE 754 format
  • numbers in js are limited by Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER and Number.MIN_SAFE_INTEGER
  • bigint is used to represent numbers which can be infinitely large

Undefined vs Undeclared

  • a variable is undefined when variable v has been allocated memory, but it doesn’t have any value
  • when we declare variables, but don’t initialize it with a value, it gets the value undefined by default
  • whereas a variable is undeclared when the variable was never declared
  • only typeof operator doesn’t throw an error when used with an undeclared variable i.e. just console.log(a) by itself will throw an error while console.log(typeof a) by itself won’t. it will give undefined

NaN

  • NaN is the result of some invalid arithmetic processing in javascript
  • if the value inside a variable is NaN, the typeof operator will give a number
  • examples of getting a NaN - 
    console.log(Number("kyle")) // NaN

var myName = "kyle"
console.log(myName / 2) // NaN
  • NaN is the only value in javascript that doesn’t hold the identity property 
    var nan = NaN
console.log(nan === nan) // false
  • so, we use - 
    console.log(Object.is(nan, nan)) // true
  • isNaN coerces to number first, Number.isNaN doesn’t 
    console.log(isNaN("kyle")) // true
console.log(Number.isNaN("kyle")) // false

Negative Zero

  • negative zero is a part of IEEE 754
  • a use case can be to show the direction a car was moving in before it stopped
  • weird outputs with negative zero - 
    console.log((-0).toString()) // '0'
console.log(-0 == "0") // true

console.log(-0 < 0) // false
console.log(-0 == 0) // true
console.log(-0 === 0) // true
  • so, javascript doesn’t differentiate between -0 and 0 unless Object.is is used 
    console.log(Object.is(-0, 0)) // false
console.log(Object.is(-0, -0)) // true

Math.sign

  • returns the sign of the number
  • can take the one of the values of 1, -1, 0 or -0
Math.sign(1) // 1
Math.sign(-1) // -1
Math.sign(0) // 0
Math.sign(-0) // -0

Fundamental Objects

  • fundamental objects are built in objects in javascript. they can be Array, Date, String, Number, etc
  • new should be used for fundamental objects like Date 
    console.log(new Date()) // 2021-11-22T05:05:18.373Z
  • fundamental objects associated with primitive types should be used for coercion, and not with new 
    console.log("10" < "2") // true
console.log(Number("10") < Number("2")) // false

Abstract Operations

  • abstract operations are a set of steps, like an algorithm to help understand the spec
  • they cannot be called or referenced
  • they are used for determining coercion behavior
  • my goal in this section is to develop an intuition to be able to predict weird behavior in general.
  • abstract operations discussed in this blog -
    • ToPrimitive
    • ToString
    • ToNumber
    • ToBoolean

ToPrimitive

  • converts from object to primitive type
  • it receives a hint, which can be number, string, or nothing
  • when hint is a number, it calls valueOf first and then toString
  • when hint is a string, it calls toString first and then valueOf
  • it is recursive, i.e. will keep calling ToPrimitive till it finally returns a primitive
  • for the entire algorithm refer the spec

ToString

  • returns the string form of the type for object types
  • ToString of its primitive type is used, primitive type is obtained using ToPrimitive with hint string
  • examples for primitive types - 
    console.log(String(undefined)) // 'undefined' (cannot call toString() to see output)
console.log(String(null)) // 'null'
console.log((3.14).toString()) // '3.14'
console.log((-0).toString()) // '0'
  • examples for non primitive types - 
    console.log([].toString()) // ''
console.log([1].toString()) // '1'
console.log([null].toString()) // ''
console.log([undefined].toString()) // ''
console.log([1, 2, [3, 4]].toString()) // '1,2,3,4'
console.log([1, null, 2, undefined].toString()) // '1,,2,'
console.log({}.toString()) // '[object Object]'

ToNumber

  • returns the numeric form of the type
  • ToNumber of its primitive type is used, primitive type is obtained using ToPrimitive with hint number. note:
    1. since hint of number is used, ToPrimitive calls valueOf()
    2. valueOf generally returns this
    3. so, since this is not primitive, it falls back to toString()
    4. after this, and also in general, how ToNumber works on strings is an entirely different algorithm, spec
  • examples for primitive types - 
    console.log(+"") // 0
console.log(+"0009.") // 9
console.log(+false) // 0
console.log(+true) // 1
console.log(+null) // 0
console.log(+undefined) // NaN
  • examples for non primitive types - 
    console.log(+["-0"]) // -0, since ["-0"].toString() returns '-0' which becomes -0
console.log(+[null]) // 0, since [null].toString() returns '' which becomes 0
console.log(+[undefined]) // 0, same as above
console.log(+{}) // NaN, since {} returns [object Object] which becomes NaN
console.log(+[1, 2, 3]) // NaN, since [1, 2, 3] returns '1,2,3' which becomes NaN
console.log(
  +{
    valueOf() {
      return 3
    },
  }
) // 3, since ToNumber first calls ToPrimitive, which calls valueOf

ToBoolean

  • falsy values are ”, 0, -0, null, NaN, false, undefined
  • rest all return truthy values
  • note how unlike in ToNumber and ToString, ToPrimitive isn’t invoked here

examples -

// none are in the falsy list, so they result in true
console.log(Boolean("  ")) // true
console.log(Boolean([])) // true
console.log(Boolean(new Boolean(false))) // true

Addition and Subtraction

  • addition operator is overloaded i.e. depending on operands shows different behavior
  • e.g. string concatenation if type(s) are strings, arithmetic addition if both are numbers
  • it prefers string concatenation
  • examples - 
    console.log("5" + 1) // '51'
console.log(+"5" + 1) // 6, the unary + forces ToNumber to be called
console.log(Number("5") + 1) // 6
  • unlike in addition, subtraction isn’t overloaded, so it would try to perform an arithmetic subtraction 
    console.log("5" - 1) // 4,  so ToNumber would be called for '5'
  • some weird examples - 
    console.log([] + ![]) // 'false', since prefers string concatenation
// '' + false
// '' + 'false'
// 'false'

console.log([] - ![]) // 0
// '' - false
// 0 - 0
// 0

Boxing

  • how can we use .length on a primitive type string?
  • boxing happens implicitly, i.e. gets wrapped with String fundamental object
var name = "kyle"
console.log(name.length) // 4

Using Coercion

  • we should use coercion to our strength, to make code more readable, and not rely on weird corner cases
  • coercion should be used wisely, as it can result in problems
  • types should be checked properly
var workshopOne = { topic: null };
var workshopTwo = {};

if (
  (workshopOne.topic === null || workshopOne.topic === undefined) &&
  (workshopOne.topic === null || workshopOne.topic === undefined)
) {
  // ...
}

if (
  workshopOne.topic == null && workshopOne.topic == null)
) {
  // ...
}

Equality Operator

  • both == and === check the type of operands. algorithm used by == -
    1. if types are equal, == returns result of ===
    2. null or undefined both treated as equal with each other
    3. prefers numeric comparison (ToNumber)
  • == will fail for object types straight away, compares by reference (i.e. not deep comparison). the numeric comparison will happen if one of the sides is primitive
  • examples - 
    console.log(42 == [42]) // true
// 42 == '42'
// 42 == 42

console.log([] == ![]) // true
// '' == false
// 0 == 0
  • never compare with primitive booleans inside if conditions - 
    var students = []

// pass
// Boolean([])
// not in falsy list (refer ToBoolean), so true
if (students) {
  console.log("pass")
}

// '' == true
// 0 == 1
if (students == true) {
  console.log("pass") // doesn't pass
}
  • we shouldn’t use === as a hack when we are unsure about types
  • we should be clear about the types in our code
